contextId.occurrenceNote: To "cross over" means "go to the opposite bank of the river." Alternate translation: "travel from this side to the opposite side of the Jordan" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: cross over this Jordan

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to all the places Joshua and the Israelites will travel when they cross the Jordan River. Alternate translation: "everywhere you go in this land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: every place where the sole of your foot will walk

contextId.occurrenceNote: "cross over" refers to going to the opposite side of the river. Alternate translation: "travel to the other side of the Jordan River" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: cross over this Jordan

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the east side of the Jordan River. Later most of the Israelites would live west of the Jordan, so they called the east side "beyond the Jordan." But at this time they were all still on the east side. Alternate translation: "east of the Jordan River" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: beyond the Jordan

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Israel defeating all their enemies residing in Canaan that they were to conquer. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: given your brothers rest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the east side of the Jordan river. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: beyond the Jordan, where the sun rises

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to going to sleep for the night. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: not yet lain down

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom is a way of swearing and asking God to curse them if they do not keep their promise. Alternate translation: "If we do not do what we promise, may Yahweh cause us to die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Our life for yours, even to death

contextId.occurrenceNote: "cross over" means to go to the opposite bank of the river. Alternate translation: "traveled from this side to the opposite side of the Jordan" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: crossed over

contextId.occurrenceNote: "cross over" means to go to the opposite bank of the river. Alternate translation: "will travel from this side to the opposite side" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: crosses over

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase means to go to the opposite bank of the river. Alternate translation: "traveled from this side to the opposite side" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: crossed over

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "crossed over" refer to going to the opposite bank of the river. Alternate translation: "went across" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: crossed over

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means to go to the opposite bank of the river. Alternate translation: "traveled from one side to the opposite side" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: crossed over

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to being in front of the people or in the sight of all the people. Everyone saw the ark being carried by the priests. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: before the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: There were twelve tribes that made up the people of Israel. The phrase "by your tribes" means "each tribe." Alternate translation: "each of your tribes must present themselves to Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: you must present yourselves by your tribes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The tribe was made up of multiple clans. Alternate translation: "From the tribe that Yahweh selects, each clan will come near" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: The tribe that Yahweh selects will come near by their clans

contextId.occurrenceNote: The clan was made up of multiple households. Alternate translation: "From the clan that Yahweh selects, each household must come near" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: The clan that Yahweh selects must come near by each household

contextId.occurrenceNote: The household was made up of multiple people. Alternate translation: "From the household that Yahweh selects, each person must come near" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: The household that Yahweh selects must come near one by one

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "tribe by tribe" means each tribe. Alternate translation: "brought each tribe of Israel near" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: brought Israel near, tribe by tribe

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "person by person" is an idiom meaning each person. The persons in this sentence were the leaders of their households. Alternate translation: "He brought near each person of the clan of the Zerahites" or "From the clan of the Zerahites, he brought near each man who was the leader of his household" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: He brought near the clan of the Zerahites person by person

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "mouth" is an idiom that means "entrance." Alternate translation: "Open the entrance of the cave" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Open the mouth of the cave

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "heart" represents the thoughts. The phrase is an idiom that refers to a report that is given honestly. Alternate translation: "I brought back to him an honest report" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: I brought him a report again as it was in my heart to make

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that refers to daily activities. Alternate translation: "for the things I do every day" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: for going and coming

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that refers to Aksah becoming Othniel's wife. Alternate translation: "when Aksah became Othniel's wife" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Aksah came to Othniel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "up and down" mean in every direction. Alternate translation: "the land in every direction" or "throughout the land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the land up and down

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "up and down" mean in every direction. See how you translated this in [Joshua 18:4](../18/04.md). Alternate translation: "in every direction in the land" or "throughout the land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: up and down in the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "by the hand" is an idiom that means to be the specific cause of something. Alternate translation: "would not be killed by the one" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: would not die by the hand of the one

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "by the hand of" is an idiom that means that Yahweh used Moses to deliver his command. Alternate translation: "Yahweh told Moses to command you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh commanded you by the hand of Moses

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "by the hand of" is an idiom that means that Yahweh used Moses to deliver his command. Alternate translation: "the commandment that Yahweh told Moses to give to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the commandment of Yahweh, by the hand of Moses

contextId.occurrenceNote: The unlikely chance that they would rebel is spoken of as if it is something that is a great distance away from them. Alternate translation: "We would certainly not rebel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: May it be far from us that we should rebel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "in their eyes" means "in their opinion." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: was good in their eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "good in the eyes" means "accepted." Alternate translation: "The people accepted the report of the leaders" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Their report was good in the eyes of the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "house" is an idiom that refers to the location of their slavery. Alternate translation: "place where we were slaves" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: house of slavery

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that refers to Joshua's entire life. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: all of Joshua's days
